turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I wish I could stay.  I feel personally responsible for you being here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You are personally responsible.  If I can get conjugal rights, will you visit me at Sing Sing?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Please don't say that.  You won't go to prison.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Don't worry about me.  I'm like a cat.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: You mean you cough up hairballs all over the rug?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm El Gato.  I always land on my feet.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So this is what you do, huh?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Oh, hello, Peter.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You're really good, you know.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I didn't paint it.  I'm just cleaning it. It's an original Ver Meer.  It's worth about ten million dollars.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'm sure you didn't come here just to talk about art.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: As a matter of fact, I stopped by to tell you that I haven't forgotten your problem and that we're still on the case.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: He was also a lunatic and a genocidal madman. I hate this painting.  I've felt very uncomfortable since they brought it up from storage.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, it's not the kind of thing you'd want to hang in the rec room.  You know what it needs?  A fluffy little white kitten in the corner.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I may be wrong, but I think you've got a little crush on this guy.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Good-bye, Peter.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'd like to stay, but I really don't have time to hang around here.  I'll call you.  Later, Johnny!

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'm sorry.  Were you on your way out?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: No, I just got in -- a couple hours ago. Come on in.  Are we having a pajama party?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Peter, the bathtub tried to eat Oscar.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You know, if anyone else told me that, I'd have serious doubts.  But coming from you, I can't honestly say I'm surprised.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I must be losing my mind.  At the museum today I could have sworn that terrible painting of Vigo looked right at me.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who could blame him?  Were you wearing this nightgown?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I don't know what to do anymore.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'll get Ray and Egon to check out the bathtub.  You better stay here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: This is Joe Namath's old number, you know. You could get a lot of chicks with this. Just don't pee in it.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Peter, what about the bathtub?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: We'll take care of that.  Ray, Pete.  Listen, get over to Dana's right away ... Her bathtub pulled a fast one -- tried to eat the kid.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: It was full of this awful pink ooze.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Sounds like another slime job ... No, they're all right.  They're here now ... Right ... Let me know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Bathroom's right here -- let me just tidy up a few things.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Peter, this is very nice, but you don't have to do any of this, you know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Be careful on that sofa -- it's a butt-biter. But the bed's good and I just changed the sheets so if you get tired, feel free.  In fact, I think you should definitely plan on spending the night here.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Really?  And how would we handle the sleeping arrangements?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: For me it's best if I sleep on my side and you spoon up right behind me with your arms around me.  If we go the other way I'm afraid your hair will be getting in my face all night.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: How about you on the sofa and me in bed with the baby.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Or we could do that.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Thank you.  Poor baby.  I think I should put him down now.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'll put him down for you.  You are way too short!  And your belly-button sticks out!  You're nothing but a burden to your poor mother!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Are you all squeaky clean now?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Yes, I'm very clean.  Did they find anything at my apartment?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: They didn't find anything?  In the bathtub ... the pink ooze ... nothing?  So, what do I do now?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Now you get dressed and we go out.  I got a babysitter and everything.  Trust me, you need it.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I'm not here to date.  I can't leave Oscar in a strange place with someone I don't know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: It's Janine Melnitz, from my staff.  She's one of my most valuable employees.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Does she know anything about babies?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Janine Melnitz, are you kidding?  Do I have a vase?  I brought some of your clothes.  Wear something intriguing.  I brought along some interesting possibilities.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Okay, but it's not a date.  It's a dinner.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Did you happen to see some shirts on the floor in here?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I put them in your hamper.  I thought they were dirty.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I have a hamper?  Next time ask me first, okay.  I have more than two grades of laundry.  There're lots of subtle levels between clean and dirty.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So -- are you making any New Year's resolutions?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I want to stop getting involved with men who aren't good for me.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Does that start exactly at midnight tomorrow, or could you hold off for a few days maybe?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: For one night in your life, do you think it's possible for us to be completely real?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: All right, you want to be real?  So tell me why did you dump me?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Oh, Peter, I didn't dump you.  I just had to protect myself.  You really weren't very good for me, you know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm not even good for me.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Why do you say things like that?  You're so much better than you know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Thank you.  If I had that kind of support on a daily basis, I could definitely shape up by the turn of the century.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: So why don't you give me a jingle in the year 2000?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Let me jingle you right now.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Maybe I should call Janine.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Don't worry.  Janine has a very special way with children.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: I think he likes you.  I think I do too.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Finally came to your senses, huh?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: That's not true.  It was 1620.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Same difference.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: That's a terrible thing to say.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So what?  It's a free country.  Thanks, Lib.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Hi, Ray.  It's good to see you.  Thanks for coming.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: No problem.  Always glad to help -- and hug.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Hi, Egon.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Is this the spot?

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: A little to the left.  Right there!  That's where it stopped.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I think we hit the honeypot, boys.  There's something brewing under the street.

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Peter, do you think maybe I have some genetic problem or something that makes me vulnerable to these supernatural things.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Sorry!

turns.speaker: DANA
turns.text: Maybe we should discuss this somewhere else.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: According to my sources, the world will end on February 14, in the year 2016.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Valentine's Day.  That's got to be a bummer. Where did you get that date, Elaine?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I received this information from an alien.  I was at the Paramus Holiday Inn, I was having a drink in the bar when he approached me and started talking.  Then he must have used some sort of ray or a mind control device because he made me follow him to his room and that's where he told me about the end of the world.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Your alien had a room in the Holiday Inn?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: It may have been a room on the spacecraft made up to look like a room in the Holiday Inn.  I can't be sure, Peter.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: No, you can't, and I think that's the whole problem with aliens; you just can't trust them. You may get some nice ones occasionally like Starman or E.T., but most of them turn out to be some kind of lizard.  Anyway, we're just about out of time.  Next week on 'World of the Psychic,' hairless pets.  Until then, this is Peter Venkman saying ...  ... Good night.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, you can get your hand off my chest.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: I'm Jack Hardemeyer.  I'm the mayor's assistant. What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm an old friend of the mayor's.  I just want to say hello to him.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: I know who you are, Doctor Venkman.  Busting any ghosts lately?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: No, that's what I want to talk to the mayor about.  We did a little job for the city a while back and we ended up getting sued, screwed and tattooed by deskworms like you.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: Look, you stay away from the mayor.  Next fall, barring a disaster, he's going to be elected governor of this state and the last thing we need is for him to be associated with two-bit frauds and publicity hounds like you and your friends.  You read me?

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: That's quite a story.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, I think the Times might be interested, don't you?  The Post might have a lot of fun with it, too.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: Before you go running to the newspapers with this, would you consider telling this slime thing to some people downtown?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Now you're talking.

turns.speaker: HARDEMEYER
turns.text: Look, I've had it with you.  Get your stuff together, get back in that clown car and get out of here.  This is a city matter and everything's under control.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oh, you think so?  Well, I've got news for you.  You've got Dracula's brother-in-law in there and he's got my girlfriend and her kid.  Around about midnight tonight, when you're partying uptown, this guy's going to come to life and start doing amateur head transplants.  And that's just round one.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: What is it, honey?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: It's that darn ghost again!  I don't know what to do anymore.  He just won't leave us alone.  I guess we'll just have to move.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Don't worry.  We're not moving.  He is.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Who are you going to call?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Ghostbusters.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh migod!  I'm sorry.  I didn't mean to do that.  It was an accident.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: What are you doing up here?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I was trying to get that smelly green thing. The guys asked me to help out.  I'm like the fifth Ghostbuster.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Why would you want to be a Ghostbuster if you're already an accountant?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, no, it's just if one of the guys calls in sick or gets hurt.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Have you made any plans yet?  You know tomorrow is New Year's Eve.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: No, I celebrate at the beginning of my corporate tax year which is March first. That way I beat the crowds.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: That's very practical.  I hate going out on New Year's Eve, too.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Well, good night, Louis.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Janine, do you feel like maybe getting something to eat on the way home?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I'd like to, but I told Dr. Venkman I'd babysit.  Do you want to babysit with me?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, sure, that sounds great.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I can't believe a person could actually live like this.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: So these dwarfs had a limited partnership in a small mining operation and then one day a beautiful princess came to live with them.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: It's really not a bad place.  It just needs a woman's touch.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: So they bartered room and board in exchange for housekeeping services, which was a good deal for all of them because then they didn't have to withhold tax and social security, which I'm not saying is right but it's just a story, so I guess it's all right.  I can finish this later if you're tired.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: You're really good with children, Louis.  I can tell.  Why don't you come here and sit with me?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: Motherhood is a very natural instinct for me.  I'd like to have a baby myself. Wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Tonight?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Should we go?

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I don't think we should leave her alone.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: You're right.  We should stay.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: I'm not sure this is such a good idea?  Do they know you're doing this?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Oh, yeah, sure -- no.  But there's really not much to do here and they might need some back-up at the museum.

turns.speaker: JANINE
turns.text: You're very brave, Louis.  Good luck.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Pleasure to meet you.  I've seen you on television.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: How are you?  What's that you're working on, Johnny?

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: It's a painting I'm restoring for the new Byzantine exhibition.  It's a self-portrait of Prince Vigo, the Carpathian.  He ruled most of Carpathia and Moldavia in the 17th Century.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Too bad for the Moldavians.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: We don't go around altering valuable paintings, Dr. Venkman.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Well, I'd make an exception in this case if I were you.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'll let you get back to it.  Nice meeting you.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: My pleasure.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Dr. Venkman?  Dana is not here.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Then why have you come?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: We got a major creep alert and we're just going down the list.  Your name was first.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You know, I never got to ask you.  Where you from, Johnny?

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: The Upper West Side.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: This is the one that looked at Dana.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: It must be the chemical fumes in the studio. People start imagining things --

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I'm going to rule out the glue-sniffing theory.  If she says it looked at her, it looked at her.  Hey, you!  Vigie!  Look at me.  I'm talking to you.  Hey!  Look at me when I'm talking to you.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: So you see, everything is in order, is it not?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Not.  Don't leave town and report any change in your address to the proper authorities. We'll be back.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: You pitiful, miserable creatures!  You dare to challenge the power of darkness?  Don't you realize what you are dealing with?  He's Vigo!  You are like the buzzing of flies to him.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oh, Johnny.  Did you back the wrong horse.

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia, the sorrow of Moldavia, command you.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Command me, lord.

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: On a mountain of skulls in a castle of pain, I sat on a throne of blood.  What was will be, what is will be no more.  Now is the season of evil.  Find me a child that I might live again.

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: I, Vigo, the scourge of Carpathia --

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Yes, the scourge --

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: -- the sorrow of Moldavia --

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: -- the sorrow --

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: I command you.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: I await the word of Vigo.

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: The season of evil begins with the birth of the new year.  Bring me the child that I might live again.

turns.speaker: JANOSZ
turns.text: Lord Vigo, the mother, Dana, is fine and strong.  I was wondering -- well, would it be possible -- if I bring the baby, could I have the woman?

turns.speaker: VIGO
turns.text: So be it.  On this the day of darkness, she will be ours, wife to you and mother to me.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Keep that up, mister, and I'll find you in contempt.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Sorry, your Honor, but when somebody sets me up like that I can't resist.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You've got to do something!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who are they?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: They're the Scoleri Brothers.  I tried them for murder.  They were electrocuted up at Ossining in '48.  Now they want to kill me.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Maybe they just want to appeal.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: These boys aren't playing around.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: You've got to stop them.  Please!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: The witness is leading him.  Sustained.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Okay, let me rephrase that question.  Didn't you once coach a basketball team for underprivileged children?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Sustained.  Mr. Tully, do you have anything to ask this witness that may have some bearing on this case?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Do I?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Your honor, may I approach the bench?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Can I have some of your water?

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Get on with it, counselor!

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Your honor, ladies and gentlemen of the --  audience.  I don't think it's fair to call my clients frauds.  Okay, the blackout was a big problem for everybody.  I was stuck in an elevator for about three hours and I had to go to the bathroom the whole time, but I don't blame them because once I turned into a dog and they helped me.  Thank you.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: That's it?  That's all you have to say?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Did I forget something?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Come on, Sherm.  You're my cousin.  Do this for me.  I'm begging you.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: I can't do it, Louis.  It isn't ethical.  I could lose my license.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Why can't you just have them released? You're a doctor.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: I'm a dermatologist.  I can't write orders on the psych ward.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Sherman, I've done lots of favors for you.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I got you out of those bad tax shelters.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: You were the one who got me in.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I fixed you up with Diane Troxler and she put out, didn't she?

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Yeah, I had to give her free dermabrasion for a year.  Forget it, Louis.  I could get in a lot of trouble.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I'm telling you, we're all going to be in big trouble if we don't do something fast. That ghost guy came and took my friend's baby and we got to get it back.  It's just a scared little baby, Sherm.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Then you should go to the police.  I don't believe in any of that stuff.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: This is my cousin Sherman.  Sherm, say hello to the Ghostbusters.  I promised him a ride in the car if he got you out.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: Hi, it's really great to meet you guys.  I know this sounds weird but once I had a dream that my grandfather was standing at the foot of my bed, but I knew it was impossible because he died and he started to tell me that --

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: Hey!  Wait!  Okay, I'll meet you there.

turns.speaker: SHERMAN
turns.text: I thought you were like the fifth Ghostbuster.

turns.speaker: LOUIS
turns.text: I let them handle all the little stuff.  I just come in on the big ones.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Hi, welcome back to the 'World of the Psychic,' I'm Peter Venkman and I'm chatting with my guest, author, lecturer and of course, psychic, Milton Anglund.  Milt, your new book is called The End of the World.  Isn't that kind of like writing about gum disease.  Yes, it could happen, but do you think anybody wants to read a book about it?

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: Well, I think it's important for people to know that the world is in danger.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Okay, so can you tell us when it's going to happen or do we have to buy the book?

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: I predict that the world will end at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: This year?  That's cutting it a little close, isn't it?  I mean, just from a sales point of view, the book just came out, right?  So you're not even looking at the paperback release for maybe a year.  And it's going to be at least another year after that if the thing has movie-of-the-week or mini-series potential. You would have been better off predicting 1992 or even '94 just to be safe.

turns.speaker: MILTON
turns.text: This is not just some money-making scheme!  I didn't just make up the date.  I have a strong psychic belief that the world will end on New Year's Eve.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Well, for your sake, I hope you're right.  But I think my other guest may disagree with you. Elaine, you had another date in mind?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yes, I did.  We were city champs.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: Objection.  Irrelevant and immaterial.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: So, Dr. Venkman, please explain to the court why it is you and your co-defendants took it upon yourselves to dig a big hole in the middle of the street.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Seventy-seventh and First Avenue has so many holes already we didn't think anyone would notice.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: I'll ask you again, Dr. Venkman.  Why were you digging the hole?  And please remember that you're under oath.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I had my fingers crossed when they swore me in, but I'm going to tell you the truth. There are things in this world that go way beyond human understanding, things that can't be explained and that most people don't want to know about anyway.  That's where we come in.

turns.speaker: PROSECUTOR
turns.text: So what are you saying?  That the world of the supernatural is your special province?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: No, I guess I'm just saying that shit happens and somebody has to deal with it.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Egon!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Hello, Venkman.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: How've you been?  How's teaching?  I bet those science chicks really dig that big cranium of yours, huh?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I think they're more interested in my epididymis.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I don't even want to know where that is.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'd like to have a stool specimen

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Yeah, you would.  Is that for personal or professional reasons?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What now, Brainiac?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I think we should see if we can find anything abnormal on the street.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Finding something abnormal on the street shouldn't be too hard.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: That's a thousand million electron volts.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I knew that.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: You were supposed to help me with this.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: You need the exercise.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: "Vigo the Carpathian, born 1505, died 1610 --"

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: A hundred and five years?  He really hung on, didn't he.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: That's it?  "I'll be back?"

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It's a rough translation from the Moldavian.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: You know, animals and lower life forms often anticipate major disasters.  Given the new magnetheric readings we could see a tremendous breeding surge in the cockroach population.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Roach breeding?  Sounds better and better.  Dana?  The boys are going down under the sewers tonight to look for slime.  Egon thinks there might even be some kind of big roach-breeding surge.  Should we forget about dinner and go with them instead?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Boys, listen.  You're scaring the straights. Let's save this until tomorrow, okay?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: This won't wait until tomorrow, Venkman. It's hot and it's ready to pop.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It's working.  The positive GeV's are climbing.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: They love you, Lib.  Keep it up.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So far so good.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm worried.  The vibrations could shake her to pieces.  We should have padded her feet.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Pretty impressive, huh?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It's probably the first thing my grandparents saw when they came to this country.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: From where -- Neptune?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: They came from Ostrov in Eastern Poland.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Ostrov?  I've been there.  Good party town.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Who was that?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Some crank.  Looking for goat hooves.  Come up with anything?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: This one's interesting.  Berlin, 1939, a flower cart took off by itself and rolled approximately half a kilometer over level ground.  Three hundred eyewitnesses.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: You might want to check those Duke University mean averaging studies on controlled psychokinesis.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Good idea.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Nothing.  Not a trace.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Why don't we try the Giga-meter?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: The New York Pneumatic Railway.  It was an experimental subway system.  Fan-forced air-trains, built around 1870.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: This is about as deep as you can go under Manhattan without digging your own hole.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: What's the reading?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Seems like a pretty open-minded guy, huh?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: His nickname is "The Hammer."

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Hey, I didn't imagine it.  There must have been ten thousand gallons of it down there.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It may be ebbing and flowing from some tidal source.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: I'm Egon --

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: And we're the ...

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: No, not exactly a man of the people.  "Also known as Vigo the Cruel, Vigo the Torturer, Vigo the Despised, and Vigo the Unholy."

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: This guy was a bad monkey.  He dabbled in all the Black Arts, and listen to this prophecy.  Just before his head died, his last words were, "Death is but a door, time is but a window.  I'll be back."

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Six feet -- seven -- eight --

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: That's it.  It's on the bottom.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Nine feet -- ten --

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: If you two are looking for a fight, you got one.  Who wants it first?  Come on, Ray.  Try me, sucker.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Butt out, you pencil-necked geek.  I've had it with you.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: It won't work.  There's no way we could generate enough positive energy to crack that shell.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I can't believe things have gotten so bad in this city that there's no way back. Sure, it's crowded, it's dirty, it's noisy. And there are too many people who'd just as soon step on your face as look at you.  But there've got to be a few sparks of sweet humanity left in this burned-out burg.  We just have to mobilize it.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: We need something that everyone can get behind, a symbol --

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Something that appeals to the best in each and every one of us --

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Something good --

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Don't shoot!  You'll hit Ray!

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Do it!  Just do it!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: We've found it at every event site we've been to lately.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: You mean this stuff actually feeds on 'bad vibes'?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: There's definitely something going on in that studio.  The PKE levels were max-plus and the Giga-meter was showing all red.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: I'd put my money on that Vigo character.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Is the line sinking?

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: No, the slime is rising.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: Rivers of the stuff!

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: And it's all flowing toward the museum.

turns.speaker: SPENGLER
turns.text: Late Renaissance, I think.  Caravaggio or Brunelleschi.

turns.speaker: WINSTON
turns.text: There's something very familiar about this painting.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oh, hello, perhaps you could help me.  I'm looking for an aerosol love potion I could spray on a certain Penthouse Pet that would make her unconditionally submit to an unusual personal request.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Oh, hiya, Pete.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: So, no goat hooves, huh?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: I knew that voice sounded familiar.  What's up?  How's it going?

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Nowhere -- fast.  Why don't you lock up and buy me a sub?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Uh, I can't.  I'm kind of working on something.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Great.  So what are you guys working on?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Oh, just checking something for an old friend.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Who?  Just -- someone we know.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Oh, Ray --

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who?  Who?  Who?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Aaah!  Nobody!  I can't tell you!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Who, Ray?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Dana!  Dana Barrett!

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Well, Holmes, what do you think?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: It's an interesting one, Pete.  If anything was going on it's totally subdued now.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Egon and I have been working on a gauge to measure psychomagnetheric energy in GEVs - giga electron volts.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: I love this.  We're onto something really big.  I can smell it, Ray.  We're going to make some headlines with this one.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Hey, hey, hey, stresshound!  Are you nuts? If anybody found out about this we'd be in serious trouble.  The judge couldn't have been clearer - no ghostbusting.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Relax.  We're going to keep this whole thing nice and quiet, low key, no profile.

turns.speaker: VENKMAN
turns.text: Geez, I forgot how heavy these things are.

turns.speaker: STANTZ
turns.text: Okay, let's heat 'em up!
